page.title: 06CAMPHILL VILLAGE TRUST
page.content: Oaklands Park in the north-east of the grid is a large country house which was once the home of the Crawshay family. Henry Crawshay, 'The Iron King of the Forest', lived there until his death in 1879. His father had come to the Forest from Wales and by 1841 had acquired 10 iron mines. He later owned a number of coal mines and a network of tramways. Today the house is part of a country-wide community called the Camphill Village Trust; it provides a caring, sympathetic and self-supporting environment to look after mentally handicapped adults. It successfully farms a substantial acreage using organic methods, makes and sells its own bread and produces wooden toys and beautifully patterned woven materials for retail.
